text:
What did Eastern Canadian pioneers eat?
A QUESTIONNAIRE

Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask.

Name: Mrs. John Kennedy
Address: 208, 3rd Ave., East
Birthplace: England

1. ENCOURTREY QUESTIONS
   What year did you start housekeeping in Eastern Canada? 1891
   Where did you set up housekeeping? East, near Regina Valley
   Where had you been living before that? Saskatchewan
   For how many people did you prepare meals? 10
   How far was it to your nearest store? 8 miles
   How often could a visit be made to the store? Once a week
   What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years?
   The necessities of life: flour, sugar, tea, vegetables - etc etc
   Neighbors would help one another with vegetables

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS
   What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? M. Special name
   Wheat
   In what quantities did you buy it? 50 lb
   What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? 2.07 or 3.0
   How much did you use groats flour?
   Whole wheat flour? Yes, for the year
   Was flour milled locally? Yes
   No far away? 30 miles that year? 1891
   What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats?
   What other grain products did you use? Oat meal
   Cornmeal? Yes
   Whole wheat? Yes
   Farina? Yes
   Other?

Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Yes
How did you grind it?
3. SUGARS AND SYRUPS

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? 100 lbs.

What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? 50¢.

What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? R. Pepper.

What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? Large tin.

At what price?

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? Milking cows.

Butter? Home made.

Eggs? Purchased.

What was the price of butter? 10¢ lb.

Of eggs? 10¢ per dozen.

Did you pack eggs for winter? Yes.

Did you make butter? Yes.

Cheese? Yes.

What kind of cheese?

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? Pork & beef.

How did you get fresh meat? Killed own hogs.

How often did you get fresh meat? Weekly.

How did you preserve meat? Salted, smoked, brine.

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? Not in those days.

If so what year was it organized?

Did you use game? Yes.

What kinds? Pheasants, quail, ducks.

For how long? While the season lasted.

What part did fish play in the family diet?

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? Fresh & canned.

Kinds? Trout, perch, salmon.
3. **SUGAR AND SUGAR PRODUCTS**

In what quantity did you buy sugar? (in lbs.) 50 lbs.

What was the price for a 100 lb. sack of sugar? $2.00

What brand of sugar did you buy? *Sugar*

What size of tin of syrup did you buy? *Sugar*

At what price? *Sugar*

4. **BUTTER PRODUCTS**

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? *Milk from cows*

Did you make butter? *Yes*

Did you make cheese? *Yes*

What kind of cheese? *Cheese*

What was your meat supply in the early days? *Beef*

How did you get fresh meat? *Butcher*

How often did you get fresh meat? *Weekly*

Was there a "meat ring" in your neighborhood? *No*

If so, what year was it organized? *1910*

Did you use meat? *Yes*

For how long? *Since 1910*

Was the meat fresh, canned, or cured? *Fresh*

Was the meat beef, pork, or lamb? *Beef*

How was it brought to the home? (pail, barrel, tank) ..............................................

Now homes have water works and soft water tanks in their homes.

16. Wrappings and Containers

Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

Foods now days are wrapped in waxed paper & cellophane paper and in stores covered with cheese cloth to keep it clean.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

A good wholesome breakfast porridge, whole milk, bread, butter, plenty of good milk, men like eggs, potatoes.

Jame - born - March 22, 1893
Oliver - born - Oct 19, 1894
Maud - born - Nov 6, 1895

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in eastern Canada? Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

Gathered at grandmother's house 1891:
William -
Anne -
Letitia -
Hester -
Letitia -
Mary -

Had a real Christmas tree cut from the bluff and homemade decorations. Had a wonderful time.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

always had plenty to eat and wear and very happy and were very neighborly and spent many happy visits with our neighbors.

Mrs. John Kennedy
I've wrapped paper & sellotape paper over our cheese cloth & keep it clean.

A good wholesome breakfast: bread, butter, porridge, milk, new eggs, potatoes.

Oliver - Oct 19th - 1894

What year did you have your first Christmas dinner in America?

Poveshell - March 19th - 1895

I'd say we had a wonderful Christmas dinner in 1895.

And very happy, and pleasant.

Many happy returns from John Kennedy.
